person_010.name: Catherine MariaFanshawe
person_010.description: English poet, author and artist who copied poems into Davy's notebook under the pseudonym 'Fidelissima'.

person_002.name: AnnaBeddoes
person_002.description: Anna Beddoes, née Edgeworth, the wife of Thomas Beddoes who befriended Davy when he arrived in Bristol. Critics have speculated that they had an affair because Davy wrote poems to Anna and she wrote poems for him that he copied out in his notebooks.

person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_015.name: William HaseldinePepys
person_015.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_011.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
person_011.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

person_784.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
person_784.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

person_206.name: WilliamHenry
person_206.description: Manchester physician and chemist, whose Elements of Experimental Chemistry went through eleven editions. FRSL.

person_008.name: CharlesDesormes
person_008.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

person_398.name: NicolasClément
person_398.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_066.name: JohnDalton
person_066.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

place_002.name: Ontario
place_002.description: Ontario is a province in east-central Canada.

place_001.name: Cotopaxi
place_001.description: Cotopaxi is an active stratovolcano in the Andes Mountains, in Ecuador. The first European to climb it was Alexander Von Humboldt in 1802.

place_003.name: Quito
place_003.description: Quito, Ecuador's capital, sits high in the Andean foothills at an altitude of 2,850m. It is constructed on the foundations of an ancient Incan city.

otherwork_160.name: Lines Addressed to a Young Lady on her Birthday'
otherwork_160.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_055.name: Experiments and Observations on Different Kinds of Air
otherwork_055.author: Joseph Priestley

otherwork_130.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_130.author: William Allen and William Hasledine Pepys

otherwork_009.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_009.author: William Austin

otherwork_269.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_269.author: William Henry

otherwork_016.name: Memoirs of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Manchester
otherwork_016.author: John Dalton
